ultimately, all art boils down to story, mood, and influence. it's not about making something beautiful or pretty or whatever. those are just tools to finally tell a story, create a mood, influence people deeply. 

bukowski is an excellent example of a writer, who, although didn't write like a shashi tharoor, had the ability to create a whole mood and influence people deeply with simple words. you can get a feel of his general disposition, ethos, and his psychological atmosphere through his writing, which isn't ornate or technical. it's just raw. you feel the weight of his loneliness and his cynicism, mixed with acute sensitivity and awareness.

you don't merely want to create beautiful things or write beautiful sentences. that's not the goal. the goal is to create an atmosphere; a mood that lifts and carries people.

abundance mindset is a systemic thing.

it is only when i took that leap from engineer supposed to work at l&t mindset and got into copywriting that my mind really started expanding and moving from the third world into the first world.

life has only steadily improved since. i'm still not really first world. but i don't care much about it anymore. fine with whatever is.

i learned that her father was a designer who worked in advertising. one of the things he had designed was the hide and seek packet.

he used to work from home. wow! i had never considered that possibility. working from home? what a life! i saw his office. had a plush recliner and all.

so i had naturally built this connection between being in design and advertising to being from a rich household.

my sister had a really rich college friend with a 1500bhk sea facing house at napean sea road. she once took me with her to this friend's place.

i remember being intimidated af. she had such a big house! fancy speaker setup! a room for herself! and a pet tortoise!

started listening to english pop music towards the end of 10th std. got a computer with internet at home towards the end of 11th std. learned about a field called "copywriting" when i was 24 years old. when i first explored it, it felt to me like a field only rich kids know about and work in.

i had to speedrun the cultural/internet knowledge my new icse friends had, including learning how to speak fluent english, once i entered 11th grade. and i did it well, to the point that one of my friends then told me during a conversation "but you do not look like an ssc kid"
maharashtra ssc board students get a rude shock once they enter college and meet rich icse kids. most of them shy away and cope by finding their own kind and just hanging out with them.
the indian middle class has developed a false sense of pride in the most nonsensical notions. and it really hurts them. terrible fitness is just one aspect.

good genes, good diet, relatively mature and easygoing parenting, good living conditions, better exposure due to the internet... it's a multitude of factors that contribute to it.

i only started looking rich when i started earning my own money, educated myself on the internet, and started living a healthy lifestyle. my health improved even more once i started living alone.

people do not appreciate just how subtle and deeply pervasive scarcity is and what it can do to a human. if i were to make a list of every little detail and behavior that contributes to that mindset, i would go on for years and still not be done with it. one's diet is a really tiny part of it.

most indian middle class parents do not bless their kids with abundance. and no, loving your parents doesn't because it makes you all warm and fuzzy inside doesn't get rid of this fact.

the conditioning runs deeper than you think it does.

there will always be fringe elements who wear their culture and ideology on their sleeves. i'm sure people living in blr would relate.

but it's easy to annoy even the "decent" people in society if you have the balls. everyone has far too many buttons you can press. social media is full of people getting triggered over the most mundane preferences.

people, largely, are good and decent. till you cross ideological boundaries or some charismatic messiah blesses them with the ideological vigour to commit atrocities on other human beings. then they are absolutely violent beasts with no mercy.

i once had an extended encounter with a kashmiri muslim man during a bus journey from delhi to chandigarh. he was incredibly sweet and generous, buying me chips and a nimbooz without even learning my name or where i was from. the simple fact that i was his co-passenger, someone who would share this journey with him, was enough. he told me he lived in srinagar and had a twin brother, whom he video-called and introduced me to with genuine enthusiasm. he tried to convince me to abandon my plans for amritsar after chandigarh and come straight to srinagar with him instead. he mentioned he was only visiting for two weeks before leaving for qatar to start a new job.

this is just one anecdote and may or may not be representative of kashmiri people, though i've mostly heard good things about them. 

having said this, there is a huge difference between how someone treats you as a guest versus how they treat people they encounter daily.

it's easy to be kind to someone when you know they'll only be around briefly, when your interaction exists within an isolated, controlled frame. 

this is why digital nomads often maintain such positive views of the world and its people.

but live somewhere as a family member or neighbor for years, and you realize that everyone harbors ideological biases they'll turn violent to protect. as a guest, you'll likely never witness this side of them. it's only when you stop being a perpetual guest that you truly know people in their full context.

do you have the courage to call out the oppression of daughters in these families when you're staying in their homes? or how cruel certain cultures are to animals? or how regressive and orthodox their views of the world are?

you most likely don't. no one does. it's suddenly "not their business" at that point. but on social media, everything becomes their business. no skin in the game.

another incident comes to mind. i was sitting with a drunk himachali landlord when his wife came up in conversation. i casually asked if he ever enjoyed drinks with her. he became so offended that it seemed he might actually hit me in his drunken stupor. i had to quickly de-escalate by explaining that i was from bombay, where sharing drinks with your wife was considered normal. and then he told me i should be careful before insinuating such possibilities.

this is the difference between touristy small talk and being deeply involved with real people living real lives. 

the next time you hear a traveler singing praises about the people and culture of some place they visited, understand that the interaction was extremely shallow and never crossed any meaningful boundaries. much of it is also self-aggrandizement: a way to showcase how rich and cultured a life one has lived and how open-minded and welcoming and lovely one has become through extensive travel.

i make no point for or against anything here. i've simply given you the lay of the land.

as a master, you'll rarely hear from people you've really influenced (except a thank you every once in a while) and keep hearing from those you haven't. the essence conveyed there is deeply antimemetic and takes no followers, but it unfortunately does make plenty of them. and it cannot be avoided. the same ego that sought wordly accomplishments now seeks accomplishments in the spiritual domain.

in a marketing-coded world, do as the marketers do.

another example in recent memory is jawaan. what insufferable nonsense that movie was.

is great entrepreneurship born out of such sentiment? may be, who knows, there's never one general answer and the primary motive is always obfuscated under layers of narrative.

shallow rubrics produce shallow effects and perpetuate shallowness.

there isn't a dearth of people who would spend months and even years constantly convincing you of how everything can be a talisman and can be infused with yourself and your meaning. yes, they are right, but you're only increasing the surface area of your self and your suffering by doing that. you are increasing the surface area of your fictions and your sense of territoriality over those fictions.
today, you have no notion of genius that isn't socially or monetarily lucrative. and then you try to decipher and define what genius is on such a shallow rubric. how is it going to work.

that is why momentum is so important in any pursuit that the organism naturally doesn't feel the need for, and why ambition is so valued in such circles. it needs that constant memetic influx of energy to fortify itself or it fears that it will die. ambition is contagious, just like memes are contagious.

the mind is a tool to navigate whatever environment the being finds itself in. it is a tool to protect the physical body from harm. and it comes into operation when naturally warranted, no thinking is necessary. instinct is enough. 

but now, if the environment is mostly fictional and made up but isn't seen as such, the mind goes crazy running loops around itself, seeking more fiction till it is so laden with all this fictional stuff and context it now has to preserve by constantly narrativizing actions and events and fitting them and linking them together in this endless chain of thoughts that perpetuate themselves. it develops this insane, unstoppable momentum of its own. and it's now impossible to volitionally bring a stop to this momentum. anything it does to bring a stop to itself only adds to its momentum.

it is a recursive loop of self-reference, and it can become so self-referential, it can start rejecting its senses and reality in favour of preserving its fictions.

the mind is now an autoimmune disorder that constantly builds itself only to attack itself and rebuild itself in perpetuity.

the creature is small with simple needs. but suddenly, the psychological shadow it casts of itself is heavy and enormous. and it gets engrossed in the maintenance and upkeep of this enormous shadow it casts of itself. the dog that was meant to protect and keep quiet otherwise has now gone neurotic, sees everything as a threat, and is constantly investing in its capacity to defend itself and wage war.

people today buy stuff for the sake of a reel and a social media post and then it goes to the bin, to be replaced by something else.

the urge to be cool consumes a lot of resources, both psychologically and environmentally (if that coolness comes from owning cool things) and life would be a lot more efficient if we did not have this urge to be cool all the time.

we would relax and rest in our natural state instead of being in this constant neurosis and hyperactivity.

somewhere down the line, we collectively forgot that memes are fictional and we do not need to fight for the survival of fictional things.

in general, the smaller the camera, the more likely you'll carry it around and use it. the larger the camera, the more you'll keep it at home/in your bag.

get a small camera you can carry around with you everywhere. no, don't use an iphone. you can click great photos on an iphone as well, or any other old phone camera, but you won't learn photography basics that way. and it helps to understand how focal length, aperture, and shutter speed are creative decisions, not merely technical ones to adjust light falling on the sensor.

i use fast lenses on the nikon, but a wide open aperture and lots of bokeh can often be a crutch for mediocre composition skill, just like how photographs of beautiful places get confused with good photography skills. if you isolate your subject too much, you don't develop the eye for good composition.

for my next few trips, i'll constrain myself to f5.6 - f9 aperture range and really force myself to work with all the elements in the scene.

there's a widespread misunderstanding that desire itself causes suffering. this has led many to believe they should eliminate all desires to find peace.

but desire is natural. it is what duality is made of. in fact, there's only desire, there's no "you" who desires.

and the human brain and body desires based on its conditioning and environment.

desire only turns into suffering when

- you claim it as "mine" 
- you make it part of your identity
- you tell yourself "i am someone who needs this. and if i don't get it, i'm incompetent/stupid/unworthy"

when you make a desire part of who you are, you create suffering. now you have to defend it, worry about losing it, and feel incomplete without it.

in short, the moment desire appears, the self immediately latches on to it and claims ownership of the desire. it does it not just for desires but all actions and events happening within consciousness. it cannot see action without assigning an actor, desire without someone desiring it.

desire is all that exists as long as a human organism is operating in the world. but the self latches on to it, takes ownership, and starts an incessant, compounding chase.

a desire exists independently as a happening in consciousness, just like a thought. but when your self latches on to it, it starts a whole chain of associated desires and thoughts. now, there is someone here who wants stuff because their identity depends on it.

there is no solution to this.

one day the self realizes it doesn't exist, that there's no actor who is in control there, and it ends.

a meta-perspective that may help you figure out the tactics yourself:

in any company, different teams are running at different clock speeds due to the nature of their work. in early stage startups, the team with the highest exposure to the market iterates and learns the fastest. left unchecked without controls, they end up leading and dictating other teams; doesn't matter if they understand the nature of the work these other teams do, or don't.

find out which team is dictating the clock speed of the company and see if you can work out a compromise with them.

usually, the solution is to design paper plates, i.e., produce functional and disposable stuff that gets the basics right. and don't get too attached to your work. it's all ephemeral. because the business is still discovering its value prop. a lot of your work will get scrapped in the process.

if you find it really hard to compromise and love building quality stuff, find another place to work at, where people understand the clock speed at which a good design function runs and there's solidity and clarity around the core value proposition the company is going to market with.

you can only take your time when you're working with stable foundations and what you build has a longer shelf-life. can't spend two months building something with a shelf-life of two weeks.

the only tactic that matters here is increasing your clock speed and treating rapid iteration on your designs the norm, and not the exception.

but for your creative health, it always makes sense to work with companies that are very clear about the value of good design and weigh it more while prioritizing. lots of people say they value good design, but the way they choose their trade-offs will tell you otherwise.

it's premium mediocrity. the money fuels your desires and the money keeps you working a job you hate. if you really hated your job and saw no perks to counterbalance it, you'd leave. but the compromise works for you, so you don't.

everything is perfect and couldn't be anything else than what it is. including the inability to understand this simple fact.

the books are eternally balanced, and the sum total of existence is absolutely solid and unchanging.

you try to define yourself and stay true to that definition, and it creates all of the conflict. there's no need to be one solid person all the time, and there's no need to curse yourself when what you do doesn't match what you believe about yourself. what you do is real; what you believe about yourself is imaginary and doesn't exist.

concepts live in the future, but life happens right now. the present moment isn't conceptual. it's real, immediate, and it has nothing to do with the stories you tell about yourself.

what is is what's real. there's no need to wrap it up in generalizations or project it forward.

if i help you right now, it doesn't make me a good person.

if i don't help you right now, it doesn't make me a bad person.

if i make you laugh right now, it doesn't make me funny.

if i hurt your feelings right now, it doesn't make me cruel.

what happened, happened. it was real in that moment. but don't turn it into an identity, don't make it mean something about who you are or who you'll be tomorrow.

the action exists. the moment exists. the story about what it all means - that's extra. that's the mind trying to build a self out of scattered moments that were never meant to be collected and labeled.

what is is what is. let it be itself without turning it into evidence for a case about yourself.

some nuance:

forgiveness is not strictly a choice; there's a degree of self-realization where you start empathizing even with the vilest, cruelest, and meanest of people. and given enough context, you can very easily simulate why a particular individual acts in a certain way. you become increasingly compassionate.

with enough understanding of the mind, you will naturally develop compassion even for difficult people. so, forgiveness is more of an inevitable outcome than a deliberate moral decision. 

however, choosing to remain in someone's company or lending them support is entirely separate. worldy wisdom includes the ability to recognize harmful patterns and likely trajectories. you can understand someone completely while still deciding they don't deserve your presence or endorsement.

see clearly without judgment, yet act with judgment for yourself and others. this is responsibility.

if op uses 'forgive' as what you actually do, then, 

choosing to forgive without empathy is  following a bumper sticker.

and choosing to *not forgive* is only possible with empathy. you can't really forgive someone if you can't put yourself in their shoes. it cannot be morally enforced without understanding.

but with enough self-awareness you can empathize with everyone, if not necessarily understand them. forgiveness is your default.

for example, i totally understand why my friend committed such treachery; i can see why he would act that way. but will we be friends again? nope. will i feel vengeful enough to go ahead and return him the favor? that depends.

any action i take will not be from a place of ill will but of extreme and practical necessity. i will not hold any grudge towards this person. you can't when you understand huge parts of them quite viscerally, even though the contexts might be different. i will feel no personal animosity, yet still choose distance or even necessary counteraction.

because we are fundamentally not different, but one of us understands himself just enough to be able to discern and *choose* differently.

i see him, and i see myself in him, and i may clap back if i feel responsible enough or care enough, or i may not and just part ways for good.

it is a deeply personal decision, yes, but i don't call it forgiveness; just worldly wisdom.

self-realization is forgiveness by default. doesn't mean anything really if you only judge people by what they do: krishna's compassion for humanity made brothers fight and kill each other.

forgiveness is a purely subjective state of mind that cannot be described in words. but what you do is purely rational and calculated statecraft. the source of those actions is truth, not greedy or fearful self-interest.

this is why the prime duty / dharma of a leader is to be the tao, because such a grave responsibility cannot be delegated to another.

another corollary:    

if you want your job prospects to be ai-proof, make sure a lot of the essential parts of your work happen outside the screen in the physical world. any data or tooling you can read or access on a device, agents will eventually leverage, to do the same work you're doing.  

what they can‚Äôt do (at least not cheaply, and not until we have robots walking amongst us) is all the off-screen reconnaissance.

a corollary:

giving broad feedback on a piece of work is orders of magnitude easier than producing the artefact. you don't need any foresight. all the triggers that will unlock more context are now in front of you. 

experienced freelancers ship the first draft fast when they don't understand the brief or the client isn't articulate enough to supply a good brief. 

the first draft unlocks the real brief. it is a probe that makes the hidden constraints, tastes, and edge-cases pop into view.

you learn this by working at agencies. early misfires cost minutes, but they save hours of guessing. agencies bake this into schedules because they‚Äôve learned that clarity lands after something tangible exists.

this is also why AI is such a blessing for power-users who would rather work on top of a rough artefact than stare at a blank page and go at it raw.

most people, even the smartest ones, have a hard time writing a brief and supplying context.

it is basically a lossy compression problem. you‚Äôre asking someone to distill years of ideas, constraints, and tribal knowledge into a page, or worse, a paragraph. they‚Äôll always drop important bits. LLMs magnify the pain because any model, no matter its raw IQ, is only as good as the context you hand it at inference time.

humans remember on demand (‚Äúoh right, that edge case!‚Äù) but only when they see a prompt that jogs the memory. a static prompt can‚Äôt trigger that flash.

if you don't hand it enough context, it will make lowest-common-denominator assumptions. you will either like its assumptions and paint a target where your arrow lands, or you'll find going back and forth on the editing a frustrating experience.

but supplying all the context in one go is altogether impossible, unless you're working on something extremely logical and perfectly scoped. it will always need iteration.

‚Äújust give the model more tokens‚Äù doesn‚Äôt fix it.

once you understand this, you'll understand why using AI, no matter how capable LLMs get, will still remain a pain.

the next big problem is observability and building instrumentation that can gather more relevant context than humans can recall and supply at a short notice.

i wonder how many people just stop working or earning and die as a result. probably no one. you only think that way. but the body moves and does whatever is necessary for survival by itself, no narrative or motivation is needed. 

the body has its own intelligence. it doesn't require your constant management or storytelling. hunger leads to eating. fatigue leads to rest. these processes don't need your cheerleading.

this fear that without "motivation" you'd just lie down and die is a false belief.

few, if any, people actually stop functioning when they drop stuff they aren't into. instead, what happens is more organic. the body-mind continues doing what's needed for survival, but without the excess suffering that comes from constant self-concern and narrative-spinning.

so you can just stop doing what you don't like and wait it out. you can stop the exhausting performance of motivation. the necessary will still get done.

once the illusory self melts away, nature runs its course without any feeling of conflict. it can create a ug krishnamurti ‚Äî "this is just a dog barking", ‚Äî a diogenes, or it can create someone utterly soft spoken and visibly compassionate or anyone in between.

the expression isn't chosen or cultivated. it is what emerges when nature operates without the self's constant interference. the form doesn't matter, be it harsh or gentle, loud or quiet. the organism responds directly to life without social pretense or self-consciousness. 

no enlightened person looks the same. there's no template, no correct way to be. the body-mind organism continues according to its inherent tendencies, like a flower that simply expresses its nature without trying.

why am i here? what is my purpose? how do i get rid of my suffering? how do i understand the truth about myself? all these questions are ways the self perpetuates itself when every other tier in your hierarchy of needs is done with.

a man who ceases to seek uniqueness and difference at the subtlest levels, ceases to be.

the core trap is thinking you need to be special and validate it with proof.

we spend our lives constantly seeking proof of our uniqueness. founders chase startup success to validate themselves.

at the other end, spiritual seekers constantly seek mystical experiences to prove to themselves that they're advancing "on the path."

this need to establish difference is the very primitive of the self. 

it cannot survive without this pursuit of difference. it needs constant proof that it matters, that it stands out, that it's significant in some way.

the more desperately you chase evidence of your specialness, the more you reinforce the urge to seek out such validation.

the self creates the need for proof of specialness, then uses each validation to strengthen itself, which only deepens the need for more proof. breaking free requires seeing this mechanism for what it is. 

the way is the obstacle.

@tsawrub in short, if i want you to fail because of my personal misgivings, i will celebrate your failure regardless of the reasoning i supplied for my prediction. if i'm malicious enough, i will even change the reasons for my prediction retrospectively to match what's in the news.

maybe. but it also has to do with the predicted causality and reasoning behind someone's failure and the actual reasons for their failure. if there's a match, it's victory lap worthy. but if the failure was predicted because of reasons that had nothing to do with the eventual failure, there's no need for a celebration. and if you say "i told you so" then, you're essentially grifting on a news story.

also, the reasons for most startups' failures are pretty hard to attribute, unless there's clear evidence around one or two concrete causes, like fraud.

in any case, it's easier to succumb to the allure of "i told you so" than not, especially when causes are hard to attribute, and the victor's motivation has got more to do with their pleasure in seeing the entity fail rather than their pleasure in having perceived reality accurately.

well, tech journalists hardly have any skin in the game to merit notions of injustice. yes, it would be injustice if i were personally affected in meaningful ways by the dishonesty. but tech journos turn it into a grift, almost. their incentives are no more noble than the entities they're always criticising.

being right about failure isn't much of an achievement. failure really is the default outcome for most endeavors that require a whole host of factors to come together and play in your favour.

you can be pessimistic and right, but it never helps to take pride in being right about something failing. you let that "i told you so" go to your head and now you really turn into a pessimist, where once, you were simply a realist.

this describes most tech journalism.

markets don't care about art even if they liberally use that label. but that is still quite blatant and objective. the artist can adapt to the market without ruining her creativity. but society and one's need for belonging are far more insidious. they can absolutely destroy art.

largely, i think artists are the most creative people we have and they would do 10x better if they weren't so ideologically against capitalism. but like everyone, they seek belonging, and they usually find it in groups of anti-capitalistic morons, which puts an end to any possibility of understanding how markets work. hoping the world will change for you is easier than adapting yourself to fit the world, because identity and pride.

artists brought up in elite circles usually stay rich despite producing crap. so, if you're poor, either ditch the art and find something more lucrative, or make undeniably good art that makes selling to rich folks easier.

the financial success of artists has little to do with the inherent quality of their work and much more to do with who's buying it.

if the work you produce is meaning-heavy and not utility-heavy, understand that people will only pay huge sums for it if they're a part of affluent circles where the RoI on signalling said meaning is excellent and lucrative. 

you are basically selling cultural capital and status signals. 

poor artists are poor because they sell in poor circles. as an artist, you should find your way to elite circles and then you won't be poor.

when your work circulates only in broke communities, even if deeply appreciated, your monetary compensation will remain modest. but the same piece might sell for orders of magnitude more when presented in a prestigious gallery versus a local art fair.

talented artists from poor backgrounds often stay broke despite making great work because their natural audience can't afford to support them. 

so the best thing you can do as an artist is to find your way to elite circles. connect with rich patrons and institutions. you don't need to change a single thing about your creative output.

just get better at sales and presenting to rich folks. it is the bitter pill you have to swallow if you wish to make any money from your art.
